update.description:
Hi,

I created a test chr1.fa file matching the example [here](https://www.pmgenomics.ca/hoffmanlab/proj/genomedata/doc/1.3.6/genomedata.html#example). When I run the genomedata-load-seq command:

```
#!shell

genomedata-load-seq genomedata.test chr1.fa
```

I get the following error:

```
#!shell

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/bin/genomedata-load-seq", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/genomedata/_load_seq.py", line 318, in main
    mode=args.mode, seqfile_type=args.seqfile_type)
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/genomedata/_load_seq.py", line 250, in load_seq
    assert seqfile_type in frozenset(["agp", "fasta"])
AssertionError
```

Looking at the code, the problem seems to be that the argument seqfile_type gets set to None. Adding a default="fasta" option to the --assembly argument fixes the bug, but I admit I am not entirely sure why, since it should get set to that default by the --sizes argument.

Versions of things:

Python 2.7.3
numpy 1.11.0
pytables 3.3.0
hdf5 1.8.18
segway 1.4.1
update.title: Fix assertion failure on argument parsing when loading fasta sequence

pull_request.title: Fix assertion failure on argument parsing when loading fasta sequence

pull_request.title: Fix assertion failure on argument parsing when loading fasta sequence

pullrequest.title: Fix assertion failure on argument parsing when loading fasta sequence

content.raw:
I confirmed that seqfile_type is being set to `None` by default. The `default` argument in for each add_argument is presumed to be `None`. It could be the case that when the arguments get parsed (parse_args), they do not get parsed in the order they are added. This load sequence bug could be a bug from all the way on revision 0b39771b07e1 since this interface is not commonly used.

Thanks for the catch!
content.html:
I confirmed that seqfile_type is being set to None by default. The default argument in for each add_argument is presumed to be None. It could be the case that when the arguments get parsed (parse_args), they do not get parsed in the order they are added. This load sequence bug could be a bug from all the way on revision 0b39771b07e1 since this interface is not commonly used.

Thanks for the catch!
